description.narrative:
Plans d’assistance technique ciblée aux pays L’assistance technique ciblée aux pays (TCA) est octroyée sous forme de ressources destinées aux partenaires présents dans les pays. La TCA est un élément du cadre d’engagement avec les partenaires (PEF) de Gavi. Le plan de TCA d’un pays est établie selon les besoins exprimés du dit pays lors de l’évaluation conjointe. Un plan comprend une liste d’activités, d’étapes clés, et un budget pour une année dite. L’assistance technique est un soutien non financier fourni par des spécialistes. Elle peut revêtir plusieurs formes : partage d’information et de savoir-faire, formation et services-conseils.
L’assistance technique fournie dans le cadre du PEF est appelée aide ciblée aux pays. Ce type de soutien vise principalement à payer le personnel basé en permanence dans les bureaux pays des partenaires. Il repose sur la demande et les besoins identifiés par les pays eux-mêmes.

Targeted country assistance (TCA) are resources provided to in-country partners under Gavi’s partners’ engagement framework (PEF). A country’s TCA plan is based on needs expressed by the country during the joint appraisal discussions. It includes sets of activities, milestones and budget for a given year.Technical assistance is non-financial support provided by specialists. It can take the form of sharing information and expertise, training and consulting services.
The technical assistance provided through PEF is called targeted country assistance (TCA). This type of support mainly consists of staff permanently based in partners’ country offices. It is based on the demand and needs identified by the countries themselves.

title.narrative: Directives concernant le processus mis en place au titre de l’aide ciblée aux pays dans le cadre du PEF

description.narrative: A travers le cadre d’engagement avec les partenaires, les partenaires de l’Alliance du Vaccin soutiennent les activités de vaccination au niveau national
Gavi’s targeted country assistance aims to share our partners’ specialist skills with the countries we support

title.narrative: À propos de l’aide ciblée aux pays

description.narrative: L’aide ciblée aux pays de Gavi vise à partager les compétences spécialisées de nos partenaires avec les pays que nous soutenons
Through the partners’ engagement framework, Vaccine Alliance partners support countries’ immunisation activities

condition.narrative: Conditions are detailed in the Partners’ engagement framework
Les conditions sont détaillées dans le cadre d'engagement des partenaires

target.value: Strengthen concurrent immunization monitoring through field monitors focusses on identifying challenges and guide the crrective actions through task forces

comment.narrative: Concurrent RI monitoring is in place, monitoring tools adapted to capture guidelines to implement immunization in COVID-19 context such as revised microplanning norms, practice of infection prevention measures etc.

target.value: Strengthen concurrent immunization monitoring through field monitors focusses on identifying challenges and guide the crrective actions through task forces

title.narrative: High burden States Communication plan for M&R elimination developed

target.value: Support MoH in achieving the global commitment for eradication and elimination with focus on Measles and Rubella Elimination and introduction/scale-up of new vaccine

comment.narrative: As a part of the resumption of Immunization services in the states, post lockdown, the focus has been renewed in the states on RI and along with it the MR elimination planning has been activated. In the states of UP, Bihar, Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan, the MoHFW's communication planning formats for MR, 7 series ( for state, district, block levels) have been used to develop communication plans.The Health officials are reviewing the plans with the teams. Implementation of the activities on advocacy and social mobilization through the support of the FLWs, CSO-CBOs and youth networks in on. The institutional partners, IMA, IAP , IAPSM and Rotary have been undertaking advocacy and mobilization activities through their respective networks in the field. However, due to COVID-19, there has some delays in the implementation of some activities as the FLWs have been engaged in COVID-19 activities and also getting COVID-19 Infection.

title.narrative: Plan to overcome vaccine demand-related barriers in high risk communities developed

target.value: Support MoH in reaching unreached - zero dose children/missed communities in urban and rural areas of selected states/districts of India

comment.narrative: During the reporting period, technical and human resources support helped develop local plans to overcome vaccine demand-related barriers. In high-risk communities in 14 states, CSOs have reached over 77,000 caregivers with routine immunization messages in September and 806 LODOR children (Left Out Drop Out Refusal) were immunized. In 19 districts, CSOs have supported the Pulse Polio Campaign through house visits to re-enforce polio and immunization messages. 723 CBO members, 177 influencers and 194 frontline workers have arranged 76 community consultations during the reporting period and 19,000 people were reached through the face-to-face engagement activities and reminders for routine immunization sent through WhatsApp messages. In Assam, religious influencers of the Muslim community have successfully helped immunize 120 children of resistant families. Mobile application has been launched by CSOs partners and data of 40,000 families have been registered for RI tracking. The application is also a repository for communication materials to be used by health workers during the home visits. In October, BRIDGE training evaluation report was launched. Findings discuss that 72.7% trained FLWs prepared village level communication plan and that training and communication materials need to be further adaptive to non Hindi speaking states. For Knowledge, significant difference between trained (70%) and untrained (61%) FLWs? knowledge on disease prevented by Hepatitis B. The FLWs reported positive influence of the training on communication skills for interacting with parents and caregivers (87%). Trained FLWs were found more likely to target left out children than untrained FLWs and finally, Overall, 40% FLWs recalled all the key RI messages discussed in the training, which indicates the cascaded training approach needs to be revisited.

title.narrative: WhatsApp engagement strategy deployed in one state

target.value: Engaging Social Media platforms for demand generation on immunization with focus on WhatsApp

comment.narrative: To ensure that messages are reaching even more people, especially those in rural areas, WhatsApp has been the preferred means of communication. UNICEF has set up a WhatsApp chat bot which aims to address concerns and queries COVID-19, including vaccination. With its vast reach and speed, social media has played a significant part in spreading awareness and debunking myths and misinformation around immunization. Through social media campaigns, targeted to specific audiences, UNICEF has been advocating about the importance of immunization and vaccination. Awareness campaigns during World Immunization Week brought a deeper focus on the issues around immunization. COVID-19 brought much attention to vaccination, both understanding it and accessing it. UNICEF have been using social listening tools and reports to inform our content and messages on COVID-19 vaccination with the specific focus to understand the perception around it and how to address these issues, including on CAB+. Through a concerted effort, social media graphics, infographic and videos addressing vaccine hesitancy, eagerness and availability were shared and promoted widely through Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube. To combat COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy, UNICEF has been promoting videos from doctors, nurses, healthcare workers and frontline workers, encouraging others to get themselves vaccinated. UNICEF has also been working closely with social media platforms like Facebook to amplify these messages even further. UNICEF and Facebook have also been working together to understand audience perception?s on immunization and vaccination. Through a collaborative effort and surveys [Brand Lift Studies], insights in being obtained on how people understand vaccination/obtain their information from, who do they trust, what kind of messages draw a more positive reaction from them and who are they most influenced by.

title.narrative: % of target sites achieving readiness to receive cold chain (e.g. equipment on site, ready and w/ trained staff).

target.value: Support in development of a plan for upgrading cold chain system towards a clean, green and energy efficient system

comment.narrative: Out of 60 sites designated by the GoI, 96% of targeted installation sites for WIC-WIF are ready. 100% sites have received the WICs/WIFs. Installation of WIC/WIF have been completed at 4 sites and is ongoing at 6 sites. ILRs have been received and deployed for operations at 1389 sites (100%) across 34 states. The revised training SOPs for the ILRs have been developed and communicated to all states for capacity building of 559 Cold Chain Technicians in districts receiving the equipment. In addition, the national level needs assessment for requirement of SDDs has been completed. Overall, based on current information from NCCMIS, a total of 960 cold chain points have been identified for strengthening with supply of SDDs. The revised training SOPs for SDDs will be developed based on product specifications after supply.

title.narrative: Service delivery approach suitable to reach missed communities identified and endorsed

target.value: Support MoH and State Govt. in planning and implementation of strategies, with focus on urban, very-hard to reach areas, tribal and deep rural, to address the issue of zero dose vaccination and under-vaccination including the impact of COVID-19 pandemic on routine immunization.

comment.narrative: RI services were variably affected across India depending on local lockdowns and COVID-19 pandemic status. UNICEF supported MoHFW and States to conduct RI reviews and to assess the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on RI. UNICEF supported MoHFW in development and regular updating of RI guidelines in the COVID-19 pandemic setting, including staggered RI sessions and the use of COVID-19 appropriate behaviors like use of masks, physical distancing, and handwashing. UNICEF also supported in the PCV introduction (UP, Odisha, Telangana, Maharashtra, West Bengal) and in the design and implementation of a special catch-up campaign for RI (Mission Ramdhenu in North-East states covering 72,777 children aged 0-2 years). UNICEF supported in implementation of tribal RI strategy in 2 districts and urban RI strategy in 3 corporations in Maharashtra. UNICEF provided support for cold chain assessment to MoHFW and states and in setting up of new cold chain points (Chhattisgarh, Nagaland, Jharkhand) and mapping of health facilities requiring solar equipment across India. New CCE procurement for COVID-19 vaccine introduction has indirectly benefited target infants & pregnant women. UNICEF supported in revision of RI monitoring formats, hosted on the Supportive Supervision app, to include COVID-19 behavior specific questions. In Q3 2021 alone, 35,094 RI and 33,339 COVID-19 vaccination session sites were monitored using modified checklists. UNICEF leveraged partnerships with CSO (Doctors for You in Maharashtra to conduct 230 outreach sessions and 236 camps for immunization) and private sector (pediatricians in Gujarat) to strengthen RI. Out of all CCE, 480 solar direct drive have been procured for remote areas with difficult terrains and limited access to reliable electricity. UNICEF supported in EVM Assessment in Jharkhand. UNICEF supported NCCVMRC in capacity building of 105 cold chain technicians and cold chain handlers and states in capacity building of supervisory cadre (Gujarat).

title.narrative: District specific Hard to reach area strategy rollout for 39 AD with emphasis of Cold chain strenghtening and Supportive Supervision

target.value: Support in rollout of MoH strategy for 'Intensification of Universal Immunization Programme including Mission Indradhanush' with a focus on UNICEF supported Aspirational Districts

comment.narrative: District specific RI strategies for hard-to-reach areas in place in all aspirational districts with such identified areas. In some tribal districts, hard-to-reach area strategy contributes to the overall tribal immunization strategy. These plans are now being reviewed to formulate and implement 'Near to Home' vaccination strategy for COVID-19 vaccination of population above 60 years and people with disability due to physical or medical condition. The cold chain system is being augmented to ensure that COVID-19 vaccine does not compromise the cold chain space for Routine Immunization. This includes expansion in domain of large cold rooms, electrical cold chain equipment, solar drive equipment and passive vaccine cold boxes and vaccine carriers. The Supportive Supervision application was also updated with new features and was extensively utilized for monitoring of COVID-19 vaccination session with more than 63,000 monitored following the launch of COVID1-9 vaccination session since 16th January 2021.

target.value: Support in rollout of MoH strategy for 'Intensification of Universal Immunization Programme including Mission Indradhanush' with a focus on UNICEF supported Aspirational Districts

title.narrative: Capacity building of State level stakeholders in Tier 2 cities on Urban Communication planning, implementation and monitoring completed.

target.value: Support strengthen of urban immunization with focus on urban poor

comment.narrative: The Maharashtra (Pune) State IEC Bureau has been focusing on Routine Immunization campaigns and collaterals for urban adapted the materials in local language shared with districts via state. This includes service provider videos, information FAQs, pamphlet, posters, radio jingles, TV spots and small information capsules. These are disseminated and shared via the IEC Bureau to districts. In addition, in 4 aspirational districts and urban areas, CSO partners have been engaged for focus on tribal and urban immunization especially urban pockets in Mumbai. For tribal areas, local dialects materials developed and shared with community stakeholders. Special districts plans for RI undertaken as per national programmes. IEC Bureau?s social media platforms- MahaArogya platforms and use of WhatsApp groups used to engage with communities and FLWs in all urban localities and areas of Mumbai and other districts.

target.value: Support strengthen of urban immunization with focus on urban poor

title.narrative: Final report on IDSP surveillance system evaluation and surveillance strengthening activities conducted.

target.value: CDC will provide technical assistance to better understand cholera disease burden and mapping of cholera hotspots by strengthening existing national surveillance mechanisms such as the integrated disease surveillance program (IDSP) of the Government of India. CDC will work in close collaboration with the Government of India (IDSP and the WHO country office).

comment.narrative: This activity has been reprogrammed, with approval from Gavi and GOI, and will now support the TCV evaluation in Navi Mumbai. Preliminary analyses and draft manuscripts have been completed for vaccination coverage, vaccine effectiveness, and vaccination campaign delivery costs. Data cleaning and analyses are ongoing for cost of illness and vaccine impact. Cost-effectiveness analysis will begin once cost of illness analysis is completed.
